Breaking News

Louisiana Supreme Court Refuses to Hear Duplessis v. State Farm for Seventh Consecutive Time

Justices cite "fundamental jurisdictional impossibility" and "concerns about the petitioner's well-being"
By Mortimer "Mort" Duplessis III, Publisher & Editor-in-Chief • Full Moon of February, 2026

In what this publication can only describe as a breathtaking miscarriage of justice, the Louisiana Supreme Court has once again declined to hear our case arguing that dream-state insurance policies constitute legally binding contracts under the Uniform Commercial Code.

Justice Thibodaux wrote in her one-sentence dismissal: "Mr. Duplessis, for the last time, you cannot insure things that happen inside a person's head. Please stop filing." With respect, Justice Thibodaux, people said the same thing about the internet in 1993.

Our legal team — which consists of myself and my nephew Claude, who is in his second year at Loyola but "pretty sure he gets the gist" — plans to refile in March. We have obtained seventeen new affidavits from policyholders who can confirm they were sold valid dream insurance policies during REM sleep between the hours of 2:00 and 4:00 AM on the night of the last full moon.

State Farm's lead counsel, Brenda Hebert, told reporters: "We have never issued a policy to Mr. Duplessis, in a dream or otherwise. We have asked him to stop calling our Metairie office. We have changed the number twice." This is exactly the kind of bureaucratic gatekeeping that keeps the dream insurance industry from reaching its full potential.

This publication will continue to fight. We did not start this newspaper in the back office of Duplessis Family Funeral Home & Bait Shop to be silenced by people who refuse to fall asleep with an open mind.

"I have insured 2,347 dreams and paid out exactly zero claims. This is what the industry calls a 'perfect loss ratio.'"

— Mort Duplessis, deposition transcript, March 2024

Gazette Dream Actuarial Desk

Premiums for the Gazette's flagship product, the SomnoShield Basic ($47.99/month, billed exclusively via venmo to @MortDuplessis-Funerals), will increase to $62.99 effective the next full moon. "I understand this is a hardship," Duplessis wrote in a memo to his eleven active policyholders. "But I cannot in good conscience continue to underwrite falling dreams at current rates when the data — and my gut — say otherwise."

Notably, zero falling-dream claims have ever been filed. "That's the beauty of insurance," Duplessis explained. "You're paying for peace of mind. And in this case, you're paying for peace of mind about the peace of mind you experience while unconscious."

Opinion • From the Editor's Desk

Why I Insured My Own Funeral (In a Dream, During a Full Moon, Twice)

By Mort Duplessis III • Opinion

My grandfather, Mortimer Duplessis the First, used to say: "Boy, there are two things in life you can count on: death and people wanting to talk about their dreams." Pawpaw was right about the first thing. The second thing turned out to be more of a business opportunity than he ever could have imagined.

I have been a licensed funeral director in the state of Louisiana since 2003. I have embalmed over 1,200 people. I have seen death from every angle and in every stage of its bureaucratic aftermath. But it wasn't until the full moon of September 14th, 2019, that I truly understood the gap in the market.

That night, I fell asleep in my recliner watching the Saints game. I dreamed I was at my own funeral — lovely service, great turnout, my ex-wife Charlene did NOT attend which was the most realistic part — and when the bill came, nobody could pay it. Dream-me panicked. Dream-me thought: what if someone could have sold me a policy, right here, right now, in this dream?

I woke up at 3:47 AM with the full moon shining through my window and I knew. I knew. I called my nephew Claude — he was fourteen at the time — and I said, "Claude, I'm starting an insurance company." He said, "Uncle Mort, it's four in the morning." I said, "In dreams, it's always four in the morning." He hung up. But the seed was planted.

Six years later, I have eleven policyholders, a newspaper, and a pending Supreme Court case. My ex-wife's lawyer says I should "seek help." My actual therapist, Dr. Robicheaux, says what I'm doing is "not technically therapy-adjacent" but she admires my "commitment to a bit." It's not a bit, Dr. Robicheaux. It's a calling.

I insured my own funeral dream twice because the first policy had a typo (I accidentally listed the cause of death as "vibes"). The second policy is airtight. $12.99/month. Covers funeral costs up to $8,000 in dream-dollars, which convert to real dollars at a rate I will determine when the time comes.

Opinion

GUEST COLUMN: My Uncle Mort Is Not Well and I Want That on the Record

By Claude Duplessis, Loyola Law 2L • Guest Contributor (under duress)

My uncle asked me to write a column about "the future of dream jurisprudence." I am writing this column instead because I need to publicly state that I am not a lawyer yet, I have never reviewed any of the "policies" he claims to have written, and I am deeply uncomfortable that he lists me as General Counsel on his Venmo business profile.

Uncle Mort is the kindest man I know. He gave me my first job (scrubbing caskets at age 11, which in retrospect was probably illegal). He taught me to fish. He has never once missed a birthday. He also believes — sincerely, with his whole chest — that he can sell insurance to sleeping people during a full moon, and I do not know how to help him.

For the record: I have told him at least forty times that dream insurance is not a real category of insurance. He responds by showing me his "actuarial tables," which are handwritten in a composition notebook and include entries like "Dream Type: teeth falling out. Risk Level: EMOTIONAL." He has a category called "Being Chased (Unspecified)" that he's rated as a 7 out of 10 on his proprietary danger scale. I asked what a 10 was. He said, "Dreaming about your own funeral and the caterer brought potato salad with raisins." I couldn't argue with that.

If you are reading this, please do not send my uncle money via Venmo. If you have already sent my uncle money via Venmo, please contact me at the Loyola Law School clinic. We are not equipped for this but honestly neither is anyone.

Dream Obituaries

We honor the dreams that didn't make it through the night.

The One Where You Could Fly
b. approx. 2:30 AM • d. 2:31 AM (alarm clock)

This dream passed suddenly and without warning at the cruel hands of a 6:00 AM alarm set for a job the dreamer doesn't even like. Survivors include a lingering sense of wonder and the vague feeling that gravity is optional. In lieu of flowers, please hit the snooze button.

That Recurring Exam Dream
b. September 1998 • d. Still alive, unfortunately

Reports of this dream's death have been greatly exaggerated. Now in its 28th year, the dream in which you arrive to a final exam you never studied for in a class you didn't know you were enrolled in continues to visit the dreamer approximately four times per month. The dream could not be reached for comment but sources say it "feeds on anxiety and shows no signs of slowing down."

The One About the House With Extra Rooms
b. 3:12 AM • d. 3:14 AM (bathroom trip)

A beloved and mysterious dream in which your house suddenly has rooms you never knew about — a greenhouse, a ballroom, a second kitchen that's somehow better than your real kitchen. Died when the dreamer got up to pee and couldn't get back to it. Predeceased by a similar dream about a swimming pool in the basement (2019). Memorial service pending.

The One Where Your Ex Apologized
b. 1:45 AM • d. 1:46 AM (dreamer started laughing in their sleep)

Even the subconscious couldn't keep a straight face on this one. Described by the dreamer as "the most realistic thing I've ever experienced for approximately nine seconds before I remembered who we're talking about." Survived by unresolved resentment and a Spotify playlist titled "Songs That Aren't About Charlene."

Dear Editor,
I would like a refund. Last Tuesday I dreamed I was being audited by the IRS and your policy didn't cover it. The fine print says "government-related dreams excluded." What kind of insurance doesn't cover the government?

— Patricia M., Kenner
Patricia, as our policy clearly states (pg. 4, footnote 11, written in 6pt font), government-related dreams fall under the "Acts of Bureaucracy" exclusion. We also do not cover dreams involving jury duty, the DMV, or the post office. These are considered acts of God.

Dear Editor,

— Brenda Hebert, Lead Counsel, State Farm Louisiana
Brenda, we've published your letter as a courtesy. We note that you are a frequent writer to this column and we appreciate your readership. Annual subscription rate is $18. We accept Venmo.

Dear Editor,
My husband has been talking about your "dream insurance" for six years now. At Thanksgiving, he tried to sell a policy to my mother. She is 84. She was asleep at the table. He said it counted. Does it count?

— Charlene D., Baton Rouge

Corrections & Clarifications
January Full Moon Edition: An article titled "Dream GDP Reaches All-Time High" incorrectly stated that the dream economy had surpassed Belgium's GDP. In fact, the correct comparison was to the GDP of a very small Belgium. We regret the overstatement.
January Full Moon Edition: The photo accompanying "Local Man Insures Nap" was not, as captioned, a stock photo. It was a real photo of the publisher asleep in his recliner. We apologize to the publisher's dignity.
December Full Moon Edition: In our holiday gift guide, we recommended "A SomnoShield Premium Policy" as a stocking stuffer. Several readers pointed out that a Venmo payment is not a physical object and cannot fit in a stocking. This is technically correct but lacks imagination.
December Full Moon Edition: We incorrectly stated that Brenda Hebert of State Farm "secretly reads the Gazette every month." Ms. Hebert's attorney has informed us that she reads it "only to gather evidence for the restraining order." We stand corrected and are flattered.
November Full Moon Edition: Our obituary for "The Dream Where You Can Breathe Underwater" prematurely declared this dream dead. Three readers reported experiencing it the following week. We are glad it has made a full recovery and wish it continued health.
October Full Moon Edition: We reported that the publisher's nephew Claude "enthusiastically supports" the family dream insurance business. Claude has asked us to print the following statement: "I do not. Please stop." We have printed his statement and respectfully disagree.
